byline.original: By LIZ ALDERMAN and DAVID BARBOZA
byline.contributor: Liz Alderman reported from Paris, and David Barboza from Beijing. Keith Bradsher contributed reporting from Hong Kong.

abstract: European leaders open talks with China a day after they unveil their latest plan to save the euro, hoping that the Chinese government will invest in Europe's emergency stability fund; Chinese are expected to demand major concessions for any deal, which would give China its biggest opportunity yet to exercise financial clout in the Western world.
snippet: Beijing is expected to demand major concessions in any deal, which would be perhaps its biggest opportunity yet to exercise financial clout in the West.
lead_paragraph: Beijing is expected to demand major concessions in any deal, which would be perhaps its biggest opportunity yet to exercise financial clout in the West.

headline.main: Europe Tries to Lure Chinese Cash to Back Rescue of Euro
headline.print_headline: China Is Asked For Investment In Euro Rescue
headline.seo: Europe Seeks Chinese Investment in Euro Rescue
